explanation:
For a sound MISRA C "no unreachable code" analysis we must know definitions/semantics that affect compile-time/expand-time control flow and any constructs that the compiler can prove make code unreachable. Each listed symbol is required for the following reasons:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro): may expand to an immediate return, longjmp, or abort (noreturn). If it contains a return/abort the subsequent code could become unreachable; need its expansion to determine that.
- OS_CHECK_STRING (macro): used with sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt) and may expand to return/abort; also its use of sizeof(...) depends on the filesys type. Its definition is needed to see if it makes later code unreachable.
- OS_CHECK_PATHNAME (macro): same as above—could expand to an unconditional return/abort or other control-flow affecting constructs.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET (macro): expands to access the global object table; macro body could include control-flow (e.g., asserts/returns). Also it uses the OS_filesys_table symbol.
- OS_OBJECT_INIT (macro): may include initialization code that could return/abort or otherwise affect reachability; need expansion.
- OS_filesys_internal_record_t (type): required so sizeof(filesys->volume_name) and sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt) are known at compile time and to verify that using sizeof(filesys->...) before filesys is assigned is legitimate and what sizes the memchr/strncpy calls receive.
- OS_object_token_t (type): token variable type may affect macro expansions (passed by address) and any attributes; need its declaration.
- OS_filesys_table (global): used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; the macro expansion may reference it and its type/definition can affect reachability if, for example, the macro depends on table state in ways visible at compile time for static analysis of unreachable code.
- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew (function): its prototype/attributes matter (e.g., if annotated noreturn or as a macro that always returns non-success at compile-time); also it is the conditional that controls the big if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) block — need its semantics to determine if that block can be reached.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew (function): may be annotated noreturn or have side-effects; its definition/attributes can affect whether code after its call (if any) is reachable. Also used to finalize and return; its signature influences compile-time control-flow reasoning.
- OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl (function): called inside the success path; if this function is annotated noreturn (or a macro that always fails/returns), the subsequent code may be unreachable — need its declaration/attributes.
- OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl (function): same reason as StartVolume_Impl — its attributes/semantics can affect reachability of code following its call.
- OS_SUCCESS (constant): the value compared against return_code controls which branches are possible; the analysis needs its value to reason about the if conditions when combined with known return behavior/annotations of called functions.
- OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (constant): returned directly under a condition; included so that the set of possible return values is known for reachability analysis.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE (constant): passed to OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew; while not directly affecting reachability, its definition may be used inside that function/macro and could affect compile-time assumptions in macros used above.
- OS_FILESYS_TYPE_FS_BASED, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_FIXED, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_READY, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM, OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL (constants/flags): these are written into the filesys record; their definitions/attributes are needed if any are implemented as macros with side effects (unlikely) or if their definitions are used by macros that could affect control flow. They are included to be comprehensive when analyzing the modifications in the success path and to confirm these writes do not themselves contain control-flow that would mark subsequent code unreachable.

In short: the CHECK_* and OBJECT_* macros and the called functions/impls may contain returns/aborts/noreturn attributes that make subsequent source text unreachable at compile/expand time; the filesys record/type and associated constants are needed so compile-time-evaluable expressions (sizeof) and macro arguments can be resolved. Knowing all these definitions is necessary to determine whether any portion of the function is provably unreachable according to MISRA C.
